ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: how to write effectively as a form of resistance, reflecting on the readings we did

I learned how to write in a completely different way in this course. Moving away from the stabdard essay model in college, I learned to write in a way that the public could consume my work and I think my writing is better for it.
Learned how to read public pieces critically, how to evaluate them and how to draw from them to write my own pieces
A lot about the writing within different subcultures and groups and the ways that people write about those groups or from within them.
I strengthened my abilities to critically analyze writing especially in a college seminar style

I gained more insight into the key issues the class dived into  #MeToo, politics of public space, migration, race, climate change, evictions, among others. The readings were incredibly interesting, and the weekly discussion posts & seminars were helpful spaces to formulate thoughts on them & process them together. I also had space to think more about the role of the public intellectual, the purpose of my education at Yale at large, and the ways I engage with the issues we encounter in class.

how to write engaging public pieces about timely and important topics! we got to hear from different guest speakers and read very interesting op-eds and public-facing pieces about different topics, from climate change to immigration to metaphorically walking in the shoes of different marginalized groups. the readings were always fascinating and not difficult to understand. i feel like i gained so much knowledge not just from the readings but also from weekly discussions in class.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Lots of great readings and open-ended papers, which I enjoyed. Can't think of weaknesses.
I loved all of the discussions and how engaged Professor Jelly-Schapiro was with all of our thoughts. We covered a lot of issues in the class and the discussions always felt inclusive of everyone.
The biggest strength was how accessible and engaging the readings were. I particularly enjoyed Desmonds Evicted

This courses syllabus was particularly strong and I enjoyed the instructor guidance through our readings. I think it could have been more focused in which readings to focus on / what angle per class we would be looking at the text through

Strengths: It was super engaging! Course readings were a blast (and short too!), and from a wide array of different sources, so it was really easy and engaging to just have a conversation about those pieces. We had weekly discussion posts that Professor would also read and pull into our conversations, so it felt that all of the material that we were covering was getting used.

Weaknesses: I don't have anything to say here!
I honestly loved this course and don't think it has any weaknesses that stand out -- I think that a big strength was that it met once a week

Strengths: the readings were all very interesting, without being too intense! Prof. Jelly-Schapiro brought in engaging, insightful speakers, and the class was a friendly, welcoming space. Weaknesses: the course is deeply, deeply US-centric  while this isn't a bad thing in itself, I wish I had known about this before I chose the course

strengths: interesting pieces, relatively low workload, very high reward
weaknesses: it was at 9:25 in the morning which made getting up hard, but i would say overall it was worth it.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, you will read lots of great authors on varied topics related to social justice. You will also get a chance to write about something that you deeply care about for the final.
Yes, if youre interested in public writing, this class is really amazing. Fun assignments which allow you to use your voice in ways many academic papers do not.
Yes, take this class!

Yes! I think this iteration of the course was very valuable in teaching me to write in a specific way and the prof clearly had expertise in what audiences to target/how to write in a way that would have impact in the world

Yes! But this is also highly contingent on if Professor Jelly-Schapiro is still teaching it, as he's a visiting professor from NYU that filled in for a different professor this semester. While I can't say anything about the previous courses with the different professor, they did receive not-so-good ratings from previous students, which is a little bit telling.
Yes
If the readings excite you, sure! I don't think I gained anything too special from the course, skills-wise, but it was a fun space to think about some interesting pieces once-a-week.
YES absolutely!! it really makes you think and engage with the world. i felt like i gained so many new perspectives. and the workload was not bad at all.
